frameDefinitions: This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
This frame involves a Creator making a duplicate, the Copy, of some Original entity.
A Cognizer has a relatively fixed positive or negative point of view towards an Issue.

This frame consists of words that describe a hostile encounter between opposing forces (Side_1 and Side_2, collectively conceptualizable as Sides) over a disputed Issue and/or in order to reach a specific  Purpose. '' 'He still wants to fight Mike Tyson in about 8 months.'
A Sender plans the Path (along with Source and Goal) of a Theme and places it in circumstances such that it travels along this Path under the power of some entity other than the Sender.
This frame concerns a specific subset of Instances of a Type which are evaluated in terms of their similarity to a conceptual prototype of the Type.
frameExamples: The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
The teacher <t>copied</t> the problem onto the blackboard.
In interviews , it seems like everyone is completely <t>against</t> this expenditure .
He still wants to <t>fight</t> Mike Tyson in about 8 months.
I <t>sent</t> the manuscript to England to Bill.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
The <fen>Creator</fen> produces the <fen>Copy</fen> based on the <fen>Original</fen>.  It is normally expressed as an External Argument.
The <fen>Original</fen> is the entity which is copied. With verbs it is frequently expressed as an NP Object:
The <fen>Copy</fen> produced by the <fen>Creator</fen> is frequently not expressed. However, when <fen>Copy</fen> does occur, it is usually expressed as the External Argument of verbs:
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes <fen>Place</fen>.
The individual that holds an opinion on an <fen>Issue</fen> or Side.
The matter, usually concerning a course of action, which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a positive or negative opinion about.
The party or individual (generally associated with a particular position on an <fen>Issue</fen>) that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has an opinion about.
An action taken by a <fen>Side</fen> or a view that the <fen>Side</fen> takes on an issue which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> either supports or opposes.
The time period during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has the indicated point of view towards the <fen>Issue</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> takes <fen>Side</fen>s on an <fen>Issue</fen> .
One of two participants in a hostile encounter.
One of two participants in a hostile encounter, usually the second mentioned.
The jointly expressed sides in a hostile encounter.
An unresolved question over which the two sides of a hostile encounter are in disagreement.

The desired result of the outcome of the hostile encounter for the <fen>Side_1</fen> or for all the <fen>Sides</fen> collectively.  It may either directly refer to the state of affairs that is desired, e.g.
The <fex name='Time'>Time</fex> at which the hostile encounter occurs.
The location at which the hostile encounter takes place.
This is the person who initiates the movement of the <fen>Theme</fen> and, unlike Carrying, does not accompany it.

The end of the path and intended goal of the sending.
I <t>sent</t> the logs <fex name='Goal'>to the shed</fex>.

The objects being sent.
I mailed <fex name='Theme'>the books</fex> <fex name='Goal'>to Alaska</fex>.
Note that <fen>Theme</fen> may be multiply instantiated.
They <t>mailed</t><fex name='Theme'>a questionnaire</fex> <fex name='Theme'>with a return envelope</fex>.

The mode of sending employed.
I <t>shipped</t> <fex name='Theme'>the crops</fex> <fex name='Transport_means'>by bigrig </fex>.

This is the recipient of the sent <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fex name='Sender'>Tess</fex> <t>mailed</t> <fex name='Theme'>a letter</fex> <fex name='Recipient'> to Abby</fex>
When the sending takes place
A spatial setting encomnpassing the Source location, where the Sending event takes place.
A thing or episode that is considered exemplary of a certain <fen>Type</fen>.
The category of things or events from which an <fen>Instance</fen> is picked out.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Sue</fex> responded to the objection convincingly.
Sue answered <fex>Bob</fex> immediately.
<fex>'I can't help you,'</fex> Sue answered.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
Sue answered <fex>the question</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
<fex>Pat</fex> photocopied the article.
Pat photocopied <fex>the article</fex>.
<fex>The results</fex> replicate those of an earlier study.
<fex>Last year</fex> she opposed the bill, but changed her mind after she received correspondence supporting the bill.
While <fex>the U.S.'s</fex> battle with terrorist-harboring nations is far off ...
While the U.S.'s battle <fex>with terrorist-harboring nations</fex> is far off ...
<fex>They</fex> fought over the right to own land.
They had a dust-up <fex>over who was prettier</fex> .
He dueled with his former second <fex>to defend the honour of the man he had killed</fex> .
Following the battle of Naseby <fex>in 1645</fex> he died.
Following the battle <fex>of Naseby</fex> in 1645 ...
I sent the letter to you <fex>last week</fex>.
Barney posted the letter on Monday <fex>in Athens</fex>
